Author: DanielBMarkham
Content:
So if you're a mechanic making $40K a year and win the lottery or something for one year and make $200K, you're rich and owe the rest of us a greater percentage than you did the year before?

Likewise if you're a multimillionaire video-store owner who has a bad year and only makes $40K you're poor, and deserve some money from the mechanic?

What ever happened to the idea of treating each voter the same as every other voter? It seems to me like any kind of segmenting -- by income, by net worth, by religion, by race, by looks, etc -- starts to pit groups of people against each other.

I don't think there are lines, or rather I think drawing them is a really bad idea.

Author: robotrout
Content:
This "bugger your neighbor" attitude that prevails in this country is removing every freedom that we teach our children make this country great.

Hell yes. Take more money at the point of a gun, why not? They have more money than you do, the greedy bastards. They don't deserve it. You deserve that money, or you know somebody that does. Go for it!

Author: gstar
Content:
Absolutely - I'd advise licensing if you can so that you own the code, and if you'd like to retain the libraries you will have to anyway.

You'll absolutely need a lawyer.

Lawyers who deal with IP at this level are usually hard to find - where are you located, maybe HN can help you find someone?

Title: 4 Reasons We Must Redefine Web Application Security

Author: DavidSJ
Content:
If I said "woman need to be protected from politics", I think you'd justifiably interpret that as suggesting that they be protected from themselves. Maybe you think they should be protected from themselves, but that is what you're doing, essentially, when you try to shield someone from exposure to ideas and the capacity/responsibility to make judgments about those ideas.

Put another way: you're trying to deny them the opportunity to make a certain choice (that is, vote) for their own good. That is the definition of protecting someone from them-self.

Author: divia
Content:
Here's the chart I'm pretty sure you're thinking of: http://s.wsj.net/public/resources/images/ED-AH556B_ranso_200...

from the 2008 Wall Street Journal article titled "You Can't Soak the Rich": http://online.wsj.com/article/SB121124460502305693.html

The phenomenon is called Hauser's Law: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hauser's_Law

and intelligent criticism of the chart can be found here: http://www.portfolio.com/views/blogs/odd-numbers/2008/05/20/...

Author: barry-cotter
Content: The US IRS claims a right on your income for ten years after you renounce citizenship, which given the hoops you have to jump through to renounce US citizenship is a bit rich.

Author: makecheck
Content:
Since every commit (consisting of any number of files, anywhere in the tree) changes the global repository revision, you can examine the log while at the top level to see all changes that were made.

Try verbose mode, e.g. "cd trunk" and "svn log -r HEAD -v". You should see additional output that lists all changed paths with the usual "M" or "A" markers, etc. next to each. You can specify any revision number, not just HEAD, of course.

I also recommend grabbing the whole book for Subversion, which is free online (http://svnbook.red-bean.com/).

Author: witten
Content:
To be fair, the article wasn't advocating the taxing of capital. It was advocating the taxing of income.

Also, money never just "disappears" from the economy unless you destroy it. Who do you think buys the goods and/or services that your rich capitalists create, thereby enabling them to make new jobs and new products? In large part, it's the poor people. Or at least, the somewhat poorer people.

Content: I can confirm that. Long before I started using Linux and OS X, I had an oldish Windows PC that had Norton on it. Replacing it with AVG not only sped up my PC, AVG also got rid of several hundered pieces of malware.
